Given these trends, Plug PowerÃ¢ÂÂs profitability should improve a great deal in 2020, making PLUG stock very attractive over the medium and long terms.

conference call, held on March 5, IÃ¢ÂÂm much more bullish on its truck business.
ThatÃ¢ÂÂs because PlugÃ¢ÂÂs CEO Andy Marsh indicated that the company was partnering with more than one of its Ã¢ÂÂpedestal customersÃ¢ÂÂ on hydrogen fuel-cell trucks.

Specifically, he stated that, Ã¢ÂÂwe have a number of pedestal customers and Ã¢ÂÂ¦ weÃ¢ÂÂre working with them to put some (trucks) on the road in the coming half year.Ã¢ÂÂ Marsh clarified that Plug Power, together with its partner, Lightning Systems, would provide the engine, the fuel, and the fueling systems for the trucks.
Plug Power says it has three pedestal customers.
Its two known pedestal customers are Walmart (NYSE:) and Amazon (NASDAQ:), and there has been a great deal of speculation that the third is Home Depot (NYSE:).

Of course, all three of those huge companies use thousands of trucks and could easily order hundreds of hydrogen fuel-cell truck engines, hydrogen, and fueling systems from Plug Power and Lightning Systems.
I believe that Walmart and Amazon will both likely look to buy those products from Plug Power and its partner.
I hold that view primarily because I believe that both giant retailers want to impress the young, environmentally conscious consumers who make up a high percentage of e-commerce customers.

But as IÃ¢ÂÂve pointed out in the past, another selling point is that hydrogen fuel cell vehicles are easier to fuel during weather emergencies than either electric battery-powered vehicles or vehicles powered by gasoline.
Further, I think that both retailers will want to put significantly more green trucks on the road than the (NYSE:BUD) has ordered.
Assuming that Walmart and Amazon will each launch at least 1,000 fuel-cell trucks this year, I estimate that, conservatively, each vehicle will generate $10,000 of revenue for Plug Power.
Assuming thatÃ¢ÂÂs correct, the deals will generate $20 million of revenue for Plug Power this year, versus the $236.8 million of gross billings that the company reported for 2019.
If Plug PowerÃ¢ÂÂs gross margin on the truck deals is 40%, the deals could increase the companyÃ¢ÂÂs operating income by $8 million after it reported an operating loss of $7.5 million for 2019.
Of course, Amazon and Walmart are both quite well-known and closely followed by other retailers.
Therefore, I think that if their trucks, powered by Plug PowerÃ¢ÂÂs engine and fuel system, perform well then other large retailers will look to make similar deals with Plug Power.

And, again assuming the trucks powered by Plug Power perform well, Walmart and Amazon, in an effort to further improve their green credentials, will likely order components for another 1,000 trucks from Plug Power and its partner.
Further, Marsh noted that Plug Power sells hydrogen and provides aftermarket service to its customers.
So as the companyÃ¢ÂÂs truck business expands, its revenue and profits from those sources will also expand.
In the wake of MarshÃ¢ÂÂs statements during the Q4 earnings conference call, Oppenheimer analyst Colin Rusch to $6 from $3 and maintained an outperform rating on the shares.
The analyst thinks that the companyÃ¢ÂÂs borrowing costs will drop as its material-handling and truck businesses expand.
Further, the analyst believes that new technologies adopted by the company, along with its growth, will enable it to reduce overall costs.
Finally, Rusch believes that the companyÃ¢ÂÂs growth is causing the cost of hydrogen fuel to drop, and he thinks that trend will also boost Plug PowerÃ¢ÂÂs margins.
PlugÃ¢ÂÂs truck business will meaningfully lift the companyÃ¢ÂÂs financial results in 2020 and 2021, helping it to easily beat analystsÃ¢ÂÂ average estimates.
As a result PLUG stock looks poised to climb tremendously over the next 12-18 months.

However, with the concerns over the coronavirus still extremely high and oil prices plunging Ã¢ÂÂ and the subsequent retaliation by Saudi Arabia Ã¢ÂÂ I think investors will be able to buy Plug PowerÃ¢ÂÂs shares at a cheaper price in a week or two.
Alternatively, if the stock falls below $3.50 per share before a week or two from now, I would pull the trigger at that point.
